Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a Multifocal Hyperspectral Raman Imaging System for Research and Training in Advanced Materials at CWRU
Award.AbstractNarration:
Raman instruments can image the distribution of chemical bonds in matter and it is commonly used in materials science, biology, energy, medicine, chemistry and physics. Current instruments are slow in generating these images; therefore, dynamic processes cannot be imaged with conventional Raman instruments. The goal of this project is to address this limitation by developing a novel Raman instrument which will be faster than conventional devices by an order of magnitude or more, enabling the study of a range of dynamic applications including battery charging, light emitting diodes and biological systems. The impact of such a device elicits is not limited to the progress of science, but also extends to healthcare, defense and energy. The user base includes local institutions such as Cleveland Museum of Art's conservation science division as well as the institutions and industry in the greater area of northeast Ohio. A teaching module is being included in the undergraduate measurement laboratory for visualizing temperature distribution in mixed temperature fluid flow. A postdoctoral fellow and a graduate student will receive firsthand experience in developing the system as instrument scientists in forefront research.

The instrument developed in this project will be capable of generating chemical images of materials expeditiously in a single snapshot without the need for spatial scanning. A multifocal global Raman imaging system with 2D CCDs is being integrated to cover visible to shortwave infrared range. Using a dual axis kinematic dielectric filtering scheme, the system will be able to operate in the hyperspectral mode, providing a full spectrum at each pixel of the image. The system performance will be evaluated in a variety of applications such as InGaN nanowhiskers, lithium ion batteries, cellulose nanocrystals, mineralized nanocomposites, photovoltaic cells, polybenzoxazines, micrometeorites, dental decay, art paintings, microplasma synthesized nanomaterials and polymeric organic light emitting diodes. Instrument development will be supplemented with training seminars, development of user manuals, instrument showcasing in local and national meetings and the development of an undergraduate laboratory module.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Raman spectroscopy is a fundamental tool used in materials science, biology, energy, medicine, chemistry and physics. Traditionally, Raman spectroscopy has been used to generate chemical images by point by point mapping over the sample space. As useful and dramatic as these images are, it takes hours, sometimes days to generate such images when high resolution is needed. The major goal of this project was to develop Raman imaging systems that can obtain Raman images orders of magnitude faster than standard point or line scan systems. The broader impact created by these imaging systems is to expedite the pace of discovery in R&D and research by enabling imaging of greater number of specimens in shorter durations, as well as enabling analysis of systems that change over time.

 

Two systems at different excitation wavelengths were integrated to cover a wider range of applications than cannot be covered by a single wavenumber system. Visible system uses high power 532 nm laser, and, the NIR system uses high power 785 nm laser. Both systems incorporated intellectually meritorious kinematically tunable optical bandpass filters to enable on demand collection of a single/range wavenumber of interest to be collected by high quantum efficiency 2D-CCD cameras. This first of its kind kinematic filtration system enables tuning of the beam with essentially no change in spectral performance. The system can cover a broadband of Raman shift (up to 4000 cm-1) that is fully controlled by a software program that can also control the spectral bandwidth to narrow resolution less than 1 nm. Systems are mounted on a microscope frame which facilitates convenient placement of specimens and also easy changing of microscope objectives. System’s spatial resolution is identified to be ~100 nm by using Raman images of polystyrene nanospheres. On the low magnification domain, the system can cover fields of view as large as 5 mm with 50 microns resolution. The system was able to generate images within a minute which would otherwise have lasted for hours using standard point mapping systems. System performance has been put to test for a range of applications including pharmaceutical, biomedical and energy materials. Undergraduate students were involved in the design of several components of this system in the outreach facet of this project. The systems are housed in the Center for Applied Raman Spectroscopy of CWRU and available for access of users in and out of the campus.
